titleStmt.title: M54, 3 of 11. [Anon: for coins. When he was walking...]. Typescript fragment, 4 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 3 of 11. [for coins. When he was walking...]. Typescript fragment, 4 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
for coins. When he was walking in xxx the
garden, " the poor come knocking (kkocking) at the gate
and my man says "Sir, there is some one at the gate would
speak with (oyuyou)." So he laid aside his book and went
out among the poor. He visited them in their hovels. He
noted their poverty. He saw the poor man unable now
to buy a goose, for the great lords were enclosing the
fields. He went to the great man and found him still in
bed, after his hunting and his (anf hid) hawking. He saw the poor suitors (sutis)
waiting hour (ho) in the hall to get their suit heard (herad).
These were the casees that he brought before
In a voice that stumbles (sumbles) and uses the old language of
his fathers house, ))" they say in my country to the hogs
mingle mangle, cum pur, cum pur" --- he brought into the
light of day the hxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmx
xmxmxmxmxmxxx the harlot going to execution at
and saying as she went "that if ( f) good fellows had kept
touch with her, she had not bin at this time in that case."
He saw the curates in their velvet (velevet) shoes and slippers
meet to dance the morris dance. And the fine ladies
dressed in vardingalls (vardinaglls) with their hair puffed out in tussocks
He saw the young (yo ng) men given over in the s t to gulling drinking (drinm ig)
and whoring. The young men dice away their thrift; Instead of
shooting with the long bow ( ow) they their sports are lost
turned into bowling drinking (drinming) and whoring. He And the poor
are still going on pilgrimages, setting up candles and
worshipping (wirshipping) pigs bones. [illeg.] He casts the light of the new
learning upon the the old superstitions. He too, until he

thirty "had walked in the shadow of death (d ath)." It was Master
at who opened (ppened) his eyes; Master Bilney
who went about among the poor and the sick (sivk),
Master Bilney heard him preach against (agianst) and his
opinons. and desired me for Gods sake to hear his confession (confessio)
"did so; and to say the very truth, by his confession
I learnt ed more than for many yeares (yeares). With Bilney he visited (vi ted)
the prisoners (prisones) in the Tower at Cambridge, for he was ever visiting (visig)
prisoners (pirsoners) and sick (andsick) folk. There was a woman who had killed
her child. And brought her story before King
as he talked with him after the sermon in
the gallery. and he got her pardon (padrdon). Master Bilney was burnt;
so it may wi be, he will be burnt. Meanwhile (eanehile) he will speak
the truth so that the simple (simp le) can understand. In their own
tongue. Standing on the verge of the Elizabethan (Elizabetha) age,
he saw, as saw, the great buildings rise on the
foundations of the old. "There was (ws) never such buildings then
as is (if) now, planting, nor marrying." And yet the English (Englis) are
still sunk in superstition (supe stition). Give the money (thmoey) he implores that
was wont to bestow on pilgrimages matters (pilgrimagesmatters), in trentalls
in masses, in purgatory matters" to poor men sons so that
they may become scholars (schlars). "There be now none but greate mens
sons in colleges." It will come to pass that
we shall have (shallhave) nothing but a little English (Ebglish) divinity, that will
bring the realm into a very barbarousness, and utter
decay of learning."

This was the voice of the new learning (lraning), the voice (vo ce)
that ousted superstition (superstiti,n), the voice of reason, charity, common
sense. But it was by an irony (irnoy) ironically enough, the

the preacher who was for banishing and such
superstitions (supersitions) was forging the very weapon that (theat) give the old
minstrels (mibstrels) a new lease of life. His English. When he
said the at the beginning and at
theend of his sermon (ermon) he was putting English intpo high places.
He was rescuing it from the back door. He was teaching
Spenser and Shakespeare (Shakespere) how to write.

Both Harrison and Latimer see the very same house [The house was being?]
the house (hose) that was being built on the foundations of the
old house. We can still see the great Elizabethan house
whose building was to both preacher and antiquary a
sign of txmxmxmxmxmxmxmxxx luxury. in all its glory.
There it is, standing in its green island of Park separated (seapareted)
often from the high road by only a dip (d p) in the ground and a
low red wall. With its conglomeration (congloeration) of roofs and chapels
and chimneys (chimeys) it (i) dwarfs its neighbours (neighboyrs). Inside all is kept as
if the Queen Elizabeth were expected. The upright Elizabethan (Elizabetahn)
chairs stand round the walls. Their fittings (ftinges) and tapestry
are not much faded. The great oak tables are heavy
and polished. The carved (carbed) chairs and cupboards look brand (barnd)
new. The floor is strewn with carpets; cut glass chandeliers
hang down from the decorated plaster (pl ter) work on the ceiling (celing).
Even knick knacks have (ha v) survived; the inlaid work box,
the and the pear shaped lute (l te) on which the Queen once
played.

But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only
the furniture remains,, stiff and ornate, fantastic and
uncushioned (uncushioned).

Latimer had read the Lord's (Lord) Prayer in English. The Bible
was printed in English. And, using the prose of the bible
when they write prose, the Elizabethans (Elixabethans) are unknown (unknwon) to us.
When in some extremity of anguish or fear they take up the
pen they use the rhythms (rhyms) of the Bible. It is (Itis) a garment only
to be worn when the mind is in the right attitude (attidtue). They can
say nothing simple, subtle, or brief (breif). At Lady
sat writing to . But her letters are like
sermons (seroms), or state documents (satte doucments), intricate, involved,
circumtutious. She is a counsellor admonishing a subordinate;
She exhorts (e hosrts) God keep us sound in the faith
and send us health and a care to please God before all."
She admonishes Be not speedy of speech, nor talk
suddenly (suuddenly), discretion (discrteion) requireth (requieth) and that
soberly then..." If she has to descend to an actual object
a basket of strawberries (starwberries) it is with c dark insinuations (insintuat ons).
Greek and Latin (atin) come as easily to her pen as
English. There is no gaiety (gaity), no freedom no familiarity (familairty)
in this world. Fear of God, suspicion (suspciion) of man surround
the writer as with the walls (wlls) of a dungeon. The wall may
conceal a Lady Ann who is (whois)merry and gay; it may conceal
must conceal (cobneceal) passion, laughter and sorrow;
but no one can tell who it is that lives on the other side
of the wall of formal language (langauge).
